p: Leptospirosis was designated as a notifiable communicable disease in 1987 (belonged to the communicable diseases designated by the Minister of Health and Welfare for surveillance to assess epidemics). In December 1993, leptospirosis was designated again as a group 2 legal communicable disease (belonged to the communicable diseases that are included in the national vaccination program as they can be managed and prevented through vaccination). In 2001, leptospirosis was further designated as a group 3 notifiable communicable disease, which requires continued surveillance and establishment of prevention strategies. When a patient is diagnosed or an autopsy is performed, the case should be reported without delay.
